Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Transparent electrode device architecture for high efficiency tandem colloidal quantum dot photovoltaics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Nontechnical
The emergence of lightweight, flexible, efficient, and affordable solar cell modules could revolutionize energy generation from the sun. Among the contending technologies, photovoltaics employing lead sulfide nanocrystalline films have been increasing in efficiency at one of the most rapid paces ever seen. However, two aspects limit the efficiency of these cells: how far electrons can move through the lead sulfide film and how many material defects exist in the nanocrystals. Tandem solar cells (multiple solar cells grown on top of one another) can circumvent these limitations because multiple thin cells can be stacked to achieve strong absorption across the whole cell. Surprisingly, previous attempts at fabricating two-layer tandem photovoltaics using lead sulfide nanocrystals have not achieved the dramatic gains in efficiency that would be expected. This project presents modeling data showing that at least five layers of cells must be stacked before significant enhancements in efficiency will be observed. A proof-of-principal device will be fabricated consisting of two solar cells connected with a transparent conducting metal oxide layer. The research will take place at Mount Holyoke College, a women's undergraduate college with a remarkable history of educating women in the sciences.

Technical
The PI will fabricate a lead sulfide colloidal quantum dot photovoltaic in a tandem structure in order to enhance absorption in the critical long-wavelength region of the solar spectrum. Dramatic gains in the power conversion efficiency of colloidal quantum dot photovoltaics have been achieved over the past decade, but many of the best devices still suffer from low absorption in the infrared, a consequence of weak oscillator strength at the first excitonic transition peak, often resulting in more than a 50% reduction in absorption alone. The mismatch between the carrier diffusion length (ranging around 100 nm) and the thickness needed to absorb an appreciable amount of the solar spectrum (ranging around 500 nm) accounts for the shortfall in absorption. Preliminary modeling demonstrates that a five-junction tandem structure can achieve full absorption while allowing the maximum thickness of the lead sulfide layer in each sub cell to stay within 100 nm, achieving a straightforward, attainable pathway to realistic efficiencies approaching 19% and theoretical efficiencies approaching 28%. Tandem structures are an effective method of increasing absorption already employed in small molecule organic PV and elsewhere, but never before have had researchers assembled the tools needed to effectively construct five or more tandem junctions. The PI will fabricate a proof-of-principle tandem structure by employing a custom low-damage sputtering technique for the deposition of metal oxide transport layers and transparent conductors at the recombination zone, an integrated fiber-optic spectrophotometer for accurate absorption measurements coupled with careful optical modeling, an interconnected glovebox system for seamless device fabrication, and a revolutionary Thermo-reflectance imaging technique to map current flow and electric field non-uniformities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We report on the successful completion of an EAGER project. The project has achieved its goal of demonstrating a proof-of-principle tandem solar cell that employs colloidal quantum dot semiconductors. A tandem solar cell consists of two or more solar cells fabricated with one on top of the other, connected with a transparent interconnection layer (or layers). 

Tandem solar cells have the potential to achieve higher efficiencies than single junction cells. The initial efficiency of the tandem device demonstrated here is low (2%), yet the simulated device efficiency of a five junction tandem approaches 19%, potentially a milestone for quantum dot photovoltaics. The interconnection technique developed by this project is noteworthy because fabrication does not require annealing and is compatible with flexible, lightweight, low-cost substrates. The interconnection technique is not specific to quantum dot solar cells; it is believed to be compatible with other solar cell types, including organic and perovskite tandem solar cells.

A number of important outcomes have resulted from this work that warrant further investigation. A new mathematical model for fitting current-voltage characteristics was developed that is able to identify space charge limited currents and trap charge limited currents associated with either shunting or transport through the device. The model determines the band gap of the device from the turn-on voltage and scales the electrical properties (such as the conductivity and shunt currents) so that devices with different band gaps can be compared on equal footing. Using this model, we are able to engineer the thickness and electrical properties of a new electron injection layer concept. The electron injection layer will find utility beyond tandem solar cells and can be applied to enhance electron injection in transparent solar cells and transparent light emitting diodes. The quantum dots employ here are of a core-shell geometry, which is found to result in an increase in open circuit voltage, believed to be due to the passivation of surface trap states. The diode model, the electron injection layer, and the core-shell quantum dot geometry are discoveries that will be useful for the fields of tandem solar cells, transparent light emitting diodes, and flexible electronics.

High efficiency, flexible, lightweight solar cells have the potential to benefit society by providing a new solar technology with greater manufacturability and lower balance of system costs due to improvements in the ease of installation and a flexible form factor. Mount Holyoke College is an undergraduate institution that provides education to students who self-identify as women regardless of socioeconomic background. This project directly enabled 11 undergraduate students and one post baccalaureate student to engage in hands-on research opportunities, gaining valuable research skills that will improve their chances of success in graduate school. Two students have written senior theses about their research in contribution to the project and two more students plan to do so in the following academic year. Two students have presented their work at the American Physics Society March Meeting in Boston (2019). One manuscript describing the tandem device and another manuscript describing the diode model for trap limited devices are in preparation. Intellectual property protection is being considered for the electron injection layer.
